name: LYNE
description: Deceptively simple. Infinitely complex. LYNE is a minimalist puzzle game that will knot your brain as it calms your soul. Connect the shapes. Fill the board. Lose yourself in the interflowing paths of LYNE.

reviews.review_text: Once upon a time, there were three friends who were called   Diamond ,  Square  and  Triangle . They lived in their palette world filled with multicells, quite contempt but lonely. One day they discovered they had identical partners who wanted to meet them. The three friends ran across to join them, but never against one another because of their trusted bonds of friendship. They decided to dance working together in unison via a melodic vec-flow pattern to illustrate their happiness. Unbeknownst to them, they were simply puppets to a 'Hacker' trying to solve the alphabetic password to access the  'LYNE’   files.

It's time to take a break from AAA titles and indulge in the serenity and minimalism of this game. The music score is soothing. The game concept is based on connecting the dots except that it also features color based strokes/ paths and a single stroke is needed to fill each color. The strokes cannot overlap or cross each other. You need to find a path to connect all the boxes of each of the color codes.  This is definitely a challenging puzzle otherwise it would have been dull and boring. It's hard but worry not because the pace and learning curve builds up smoothly as you easily navigate few levels in each 'set'. There are as many sets as there are alphabets in the English language. Get those letter achievements to flaunt your showcase. The game also includes Daily sets which are randomly generated but need to be completed for the particular day.  You gain skill points as you progress through the sets. The points can be used to unlock many theme colors to suit your comfort and style.  Nothing about this game is repetitive. Sometimes there is more than one solution to a puzzle. Now if you are in it only for collecting achievements, then here's a  guide  for you lazy peeps. No, I don't use the guide because I prefer to work my brain and not ruin the sanctity of this masterpiece. Besides, it's a wonderful way for me to escape from the mainstream games once in a while. I am not gonna hurry on this one even though I want achievements fast. Take a deep breath and relax.  Rated 10/10

This is a perfect game for when you only have a couple of minutes to play.  About 50 new levels are generated every day!  ★★★★★★★★★☆

LYNE is probably one of the best (if not the best) valued casual puzzle games on Steam. At $3, you are essentially paying for 650 (divided between 27 sets) preset puzzles plus 50-75 (divided between 2-3 sets) puzzles randomly generated daily. The game has a broad range of difficulty so it's accessible to all kinds of players. You can essentially cherrypick which puzzles to do because the game rotates between single to multicolor puzzles that add an extra layer of complexity to the puzzles.  Aesthetically-speaking, the minimalist design is a boon for this game. The lack of clutter helps one get in the mood for some puzzle-solving. There's also an assortment of color palettes made available simply by playing through entire sets and earning 'seeds'. Overall the game is quite easy on the eyes.  With that said, I think that $3 for this game is quite a steal. I used to do all sorts of different puzzles on the newspaper back when that was more of a thing. It's great to have something affordable that I can default to if I ever feel like solving puzzles out of the blue (even after finishing all the preset puzzles). I implore you to at least consider this game if you are a fan of any and all puzzles.

It all feels very pleasant, and at first it’s disarmingly simple. Soon, though, the game bares its teeth. Shapes are positioned in a manner that makes successful pathways between them all far from immediately obvious, especially once you realize paths cannot cross. Junction boxes add to the task, demanding you enter them a specific number of times to illuminate all their lights. Failure merely results in a sadly pulsating red outline and the realization you must rethink, experiment, and iterate.  At this point, Lyne could have become a frustrating mess, but smart design eliminates any notion of such a problem. Paths between shapes can be partially created and temporarily abandoned while you fashion the route for another. There’s no limit on time or attempts, and levels are unlocked in sizable sets, meaning you can always try an alternative if you find yourself stuck. Conversely, if you become a Lyne guru in short order, there are procedurally generated daily levels available once you’ve worked your way through the first two sets of 25 apiece.

This is an abstract puzzle game. The objective is to make a line that crosses all shapes. You get a total of 650 starter puzzles and then daily puzzles (these vary in difficulty depending on the day). There's not a whole lot to say about this game other than it is very comparable to the phone game 'Flow', but with way more advanced mechanics than Flow.  But the thing is, such a simple puzzle game is just a cover up for an insane cryptography puzzle the developer put in the game as a bonus. Each time you beat a set you get 1-5 code piece to the puzzle. There are 999 pieces, which means you have to solve 200 - 999 sets. The puzzle has been decrypted, however. (solution on the community discussions)  My only complaint I had was the palette swaps you unlock as you get points. Most of them just ain't good because the colors blend with each other too much. I have not unlocked the last palatte swap but The only ones that are good are the Deep Space and Electro.  The achievements are cool too. (for decorative purposes.. not really challenging at all tho)  EDIT: I got the last palette swap. Its not good.

I have had this game for a year, and despite the fact that I haven't played it much on here, I have been playing it on my phone as well, since I got it for free through the Amazon App Store. This game is already interesting as it is when one looks at it's unique and visually pleasing design, but what you will find is that once you start playing and getting the hang of it - you won't want to put down the game. I've had a couple friends try out the game, and they wanted to get the game too. This game is most likely my favorite puzzle game of all time, and it's not just because the visuals and audio are pleasing to me. I have found that this game has helped me relieve the stress I tend to get from dealing with all of my work from being a full time student.   TL;DR - This game is entertaining to play, the visuals and sounds in the game are great, and it helps me relieve the stress I tend to get from school - or from other situations as well. 10/10

If your into Puzzles and games that are in no way fast paced this is likely a game you'll love.  It's a very slow game, but it's also very calming. Personally I play it before I go to bed simply because of the calming effects it has, and how the sound effects have a sort of lulluby like feel about them.  early on the puzzle part of the game is so easy you could infact do it in your sleep, however, 2 triangles and above will require some thought to actually pass.  If you think the game is to easy... look for sets with more triangles under them, you wont say it's to easy for long xD  Unlike a few other games I don't love this one because it has pretty graphics, awesome textures, or a nice physics engine. I love it because it is exactly what any game that has those isn't. In all honesty, I'd rather have something that is both challenging and fun, and yeah a background color change doesn't hurt either, than have the newest high graphics, most detailed texrtures, and most complex physics engine out there.  Sometimes, when done right, 'Simple' can be one of the best games out there and you don't even know because you don't even give it a chance because it's 'Simple'. Give this game at least a chance and who knows, you may like Puzzle games after all.

Hooray! Finally done!  What's LYNE?  You have to know about this, I read LINE instead of LYNE for the first time. I don't know it has same meaning or not. If you know about that, tell me the truth! Don't be lying!  LYNE is just another puzzle game. The gameplay is simple, you just over the 2D-shape into the same shape one through  n -hole(s) octagon.  n -hole(s) octagon connects one shape to another same shape. There are three kind of shapes: triangle, square, and rhombus. Each of them will appear into different combination.   By the way, you can change the color of pallet.  How about the puzzle? Some puzzle are easy to solve, but others are ♥♥♥♥ing hard to solve.   Actually, I know the key to solve puzzle. See the  pattern ! What? Yes, see the pattern!  The key is pattern of connector ( n -hole(s) octagon).  If it's a 1-hole octagon, what do you should do? If it's a 2-holes octagon, what you should do next? If it's a 3-holes octagon, what you should do? If it's a 4-holes octagon, what you should do next?  Did you see the pattern already? Is it Maths? Yeah... I hope you can read it.  So, What's my conclusion? I would recommend LYNE especially for people who love playing puzzle game. You will not regret investing your money for this one.

In  LYNE 's case, a single screenshot is sufficient to get a good a idea of what the game's about. It's a simple minimalist puzzle game rooted in graph theory. The puzzles are similar to  Hamiltonian path problems  [en.wikipedia.org] , with modifications to make things more interesting. Don't worry if you don't know what I'm talking about; the game has a gentle learning curve. The puzzles are short (you'll solve some in 5 seconds, and probably stare at others for 5 minutes), but there are 650 of them predefined, and the game procedurally generates more on a daily basis. It's generally a fun, relaxing game, but can grow challenging and even frustrating at times (in a good way). Graphics are just lines and soft, solid colors, which works well here, as do the equally soft and minimal musical sound effects. Given the reasonably low price I highly recommend picking this one up. You'll have fun while learning something about graph theory (though you may not be aware of the latter).

There is something strangely fun and addictive about this game. It isn't too difficult, you're easily thrown into it, and it's well worth the price. If you like to be peacefully puzzled, then this game-with its pleasing sounds and relatively simple gameplay-is something to help you unwind at the end of the day.

LYNE is a simple game with simple visuals. It's tremendously relaxing but never to the point of putting you to sleep, which some other minimalism inspired puzzlers have been guilty of in the past. Instead, it launches new rules at you through obvious steps, expecting you to flow along with them and disregard the difficulty ramp which climbs higher after each 'set' of puzzles completed. Not to ruin the experience, but you won't notice the change in pace. You'll grow with the game and find your skill improving as the game evolves through mechanics.  With that said, it boasts a set of 25 levels for each letter of the alphabet and rewards you with new skins to play the game in... and it's enough. Finally a puzzle game that doesn't feel the need to bombard you with needless 'powerups' for completing level 57 in under a certain time. No, LYNE does something much better and allows you the freedom to explore the puzzles, learn the bits and pieces and relax all at the same time. If you like puzzle games, this is fantastic. If your interests lie with more expansive games that take a good 400+ hours to complete, then LYNE is certainly a great way to wind down at the end of the day.  Simple gaming, just like the good ol' days - 9/10

LYNE is a fun, easy puzzle game that is very simple, but also fairly addictive. At first, the puzzles seem very easy, but as you progress through the puzzle sets, the puzzles get even more difficult than those in the previous set.   For such a cheap price, this game has loads of content. The game has 26 sets lettered A-Z with 25 levels per set. Not only does it have the un-lockable sets, but it also has daily puzzle sets that can be unlocked, opening up even more puzzles to enjoy.   About the only thing I can say that I don't like so much about this game is that some colour pallets are fairly hard on the eyes (purple background with red triangles?), but it's not such a big problem since more pallets are easily unlockable.

Lyne is the chillest gaming experience I may've ever hard. It's calming, it's soothing, it's helped avert a panic attack on the rare occasion that I start freakin' out 'cause I'm overwhelmed by a thing. I bought it a second time, for iOS, to play it on my phone and tablet while at work and in bed, respectively (which is where the bulk of my time in Lyne has since been spent).  The gameplay concept itself is simple: draw lines. Additional items that integrate well into that core principle add elegance without being cumbersome, complexity that challenges without detracting.  If you find yourself stuck, and becoming frustrated, just put it away for a while; come back to it later and mayhap you'll have your own little Eureka! moment.
This is a fun and relaxing little puzzle game.

Quite the hidden gem. Exactly what a simple puzzle game should be. The easy puzzles are like sleepy little phone app games, but the tougher puzzles will have you fist-pumping with elation when you solve them.

Everyone who plays puzzle games should have at least one 'light' or 'casual' one, and LYNE is a good option. Very soothing and relaxing. You just connect the shapes according to some simple rules, and that's it. The game doesn't hold your hand; it doesn't punish you for taking your time, making a mistake, or starting over as much as you need to; and it isn't a huge timesink where you feel like you have to sit there for however long and can't walk away. The levels are grouped into manageable sets of 25, and you can easily do two or three sets in less than half an hour — but you don't have to. You can do as few or many levels at a time as you want. You might lose yourself in the game…but you won't feel trapped if you don't  want  to be trapped.  The learning curve is neither too steep nor too flat. Having done set A and B and today's two Daily sets, I never felt like I was in way over my head, but I never felt like I wasn't being challenged at all. I wasn't being challenged  intensely , it just feels like a sustained, low-grade hum, which is sometimes exactly what the doctor ordered. The flute-like notes that play with each connection are a great addition to the atmosphere, and the light crescendo when you finish a puzzle is surprisingly satisfying.  Playing LYNE is like going for a leisurely walk in a nice neighbourhood or nature trail. It's not intense exercise, but you're burning calories and releasing endorphins all the same, you choose your pace — and the scenery is lovely.  P.S. I also commend the 'Daily' sets. Each day you get two sets of procedurally-generated levels, which vary in difficulty according to the day. So in addition to the levels that are already in the game, you get what is effectively an endless supply of additional levels. It's like buying a sudoku book and then also getting a free sudoku delivered to your doorstep every day for the rest of your life.
Good simple and addicting game to play while you watch a video or anything else.

This puzzle game is definitely made by some geeky person. Graphics are pretty much just lines and abstract shapes. Playing is easy, first levels gives the idea of the game quickly and rules stay same through the game. But some of the levels are really tricky, and this game definitely gives a lot of levels to solve. Apparently daily levels are randomly generated so playing never ends.  Like in any good puzzle game, sometimes you solve levels easily, sometimes you get stuck for a good while and level seems even impossible. Until next day you solve that level without problems. Rating: 10/10 Unneccesary quote: 'Connect the dots just got way more badass' Why?: So during the steam sales I was selling all of my cards just trying to get another dollar towards a game. I had bought alot of games, and only bought this on a whim, thinking to myself 'Can't hurt, if it's crap, I got a lot more games to play'.   And boy am I regrettful for my attitude prior to playing this game.  The game works for both casual players just looking to kill some time before going out, and those serious players who want to solve every last puzzle their brain power can possibly muster.  It's a simple idea that gets really challenging (and I mean REALLY challenging). Your goal is to connect the dots. Easy as that may sound, more dot's come along and you start getting confused, wondering whether this line goes here, or there. It feels so rewarding to solve a level you had been working on for a half hour.  The sound effects are easy-going, making it easy (and ideal) to listen to your own personal soundtrack.  Lyne is game that is incredibly addicting (steam didn't get my hours logged in right) and stands among one of the best games I've bought this holiday. And I bought it for just a dollar.

LYNE is something I haven't found in a while; a simple puzzle game with a casual element to it. I've always loved casual puzzle games but I've never been able to find many, especially in recent times. I love the concept for being such a simple yet malleable one. All you do is connect lines. That's it, but, adding more simple ideas, such as different colors and looping lines through themselves, gives this game a great variety and suprising difficulty.  And it's not short either. There's 26 sets with 25 puzzles for each one and a steady increase in difficulty, introducing harder mechanics throughout every 1 or 2 sets. But what happens when you get through all of those? Where do I go now? Well, there's a wonderful daily system in place that randomly generates 1-3 sets, each with a varying degree of difficulty. Each day, you can come back and play a new daily set of sets, giving this simple game a huge replayability.  However, there are some minor, minor problems. One of which is the difficulty spikes. One puzzle in a set usually has me there for at least 5 minutes whereas the rest of them are around a minute or less. Now that's too bad, as getting stuck helps me get better at thinking in different ways; looking at things in a different perspective. Although, it is slightly annoying to be stuck on a puzzle for so long. Also, some people may complain about the 'lack of tutorial' when introducing new things, but that's what makes this game unique and stylized. That's what makes it so rewarding to solve a puzzle that you've been on for 5 minutes or longer.  But the best thing by far in the game is the atmosphere. The sounds and the ability to change palette really sold me on this game. I thoroughly enjoy just clicking on the shapes and listening to the sounds ping off, and then connecting makes shapes gives me a little reward. When you complete a puzzle, a simple ambient sound resonates through into the next level and the screen goes white, knowing that I solved the puzzle and that this is my reward. When I don't complete a puzzle, it tells me what things I need to connect and flashes at me in red to help me guide my way into solving the puzzle.  All in all, this game is great at what it does and took a very simple concept and expanded it greatly. With it's wonderful sound and level design, it did great to suck me and it seems like a game I would play for years. Basically, purchase it now. It's cheap enough to not pick up. Buy it now!

This game is everything written on the box. It's a puzzler with a concept that sounds relatively simple at first - just connect a line of shapes from beginning to end - but the more you play, the more the game throws at you, the more shapes you have to connect, and the more crossroads you're given, until this once simple game curiously grows difficult enough for you to have wrack your brain around everything you know just to solve a single puzzle. It's an eventually infuriating but ultimately satisfying experience to be able to complete.  The music, as stated, is also intentially calming. The background pads drone as each connection is audibly accentuated with a soft syntheized pop. It's minimal, but that's the point, and it's destressing enough to make up for those moments where you can't seem to make the right connection. Think of the game Flow Free turned up to eleven and a soundtrack turned down to 'chill out' and you have a game I would recommend to any fan of puzzle games.

It's a lot like Jon Blow's 'The Witness', which is an amazing game in its own right, but this one has no island in it and costs a dollar on sale.  Seriously, though, it's a damn fine game and the procedurally generated challenges extend gameplay indefinitely.  Have it both here and on my phone and like it a lot.

I found this game by complete happenstance. I've noticed for a few months that a few users spell out a word or phrase on their Steam profile using the images of the achievements unlockable in the game. I decided to humor the idea of seeing what kind of game this would be, and I've been left nothing short of amazed.  The concept is rather simple: Create lines between like shapes, and don't intersect others. It's a bit more complicated than that later on, but that's the jist of it. The lack of a soundtrack, only accompanied by chimes and soft sounds, is beautiful. The basic color scheme, and calm graphical design, create an immediately calming presense. The level design is something else. While some are incredibly easy, others will almost certainly impede your progress, but without leaving the bitter taste of a poor puzzle. I found that each harder puzzle was only one or two mouse clicks away from being correct, and completing such a puzzle leaves a pleasant aftertaste. Not to mention the seductive chime that plays after every completed level.  I haven't played terribly far into the game, but I've realized just how clever, how beautiful it really is. I tend to find solace in video games after a long day, and lately, my only interest has been to complete more puzzles here! This is a fantastic game, a great stress reliever, and for whatever reason is incredibly useful in spelling words on your Steam wall!

Probably my favourite 2D puzzle game, it's fantastic. The premise sounds simple enough: connect all the different coloured shapes without overlapping the lines. But the game can get surprisingly challenging and can go from puzzles that you complete in seconds to ones you will actually have to think about.  I like the simplistic colourful style, but what makes this a joy to play is the responsive mouse controls that allow you to quickly try multiple routes around a puzzle with no input lag whatsoever.  With 26 levels (from A-Z) and 25 puzzles in each level, with daily randomly generated new puzzles, there is so much content in this game that you'll feel like you're ripping the dev off for only paying £2 for it.

Lyne is really well made casual puzzle game. It's challenging, and there are tons of puzzles included, but they are bite sized and it's easy to pick up for just a few minutes at a time. There are also daily challenges which give you an additional 75 puzzles to solve every day, so there's no shortage of content.  I will point out that there is also a mobile version of Lyne, and I actually might recommend that one instead. The Steam version works perfectly fine, but it's designed more with 5 minute chunks of playtime in mind. But on either platform, there's really nothing to dislike here.  The Steam version has one huge advantage and that's having some of the best looking achievements around. If you 100% the game, you get a full alphabet of achievements that you can use to write things in the achievement showcases on your profile. It's no simple task to get them all, but it does give you something fun to use after you are done. I discovered the game because I was looking at someone's profile and their achievement showcase read L A S A G N A, and I knew I had to have those achievements. It's also totally viable to just complete the game using a solution guide to unlock the achievements if that's what you want. I did about 50/50.

If you're looking for a minimal yet surprisingly well-executed puzzle game with a simple yet unique style, pick this up. Even not on sale, I would say $3 is well worth it. There's no interface, no timers, no score...just the satisfaction of bending your brain to look at things with a different perspective. It's easy to pick up, solve a few and go do something else....or spend a few hours working your way through the 500+ levels to unlock. It does pick up difficulty as you go on, and while I've only made it into the first few groups of puzzles and things still seem somewhat basic, I have not gotten so frustrated as I don't want to go back to it. The reward is completing each one. Try it out, if it's on sale, you -can't- go wrong for less than a buck.  8/10

Nice, relaxing game to play on mute while you're listening to an audio book or something. For each color in the level, you have to make a path connecting two marked blocks. Each colored block can only be visited in the path of that color, neutral blocks have to be visited a certain number of times, and paths can only cross at those neutral blocks. That's it. Pretty simple.  Most levels are extremely easy (5 seconds), but many take a bit longer, and a few are pretty hard, in which case you're trying things for 10 minutes. There are 26 sets (A-Z) of 25 levels each, and up to 3 randomly generated sets every day, varying in difficulty. Solving sets unlocks themes and gets you closer to the magical '999 points' that the menu encourages you to reach. Because of the sheer volume it's a good time killer.

This game is so much more than the trailer and screenshots can convey. Yes, it's a game where you connect shapes with single lines, but it goes so astronomically far beyond that. I can't even properly explain how the problem solving ends up working on each level; it's that fluid and intuitive. You just... start with one color and then try other colors until it works, and there's process of elimination and trial and error and each level completed is a soothing, peaceful little tidbit of satisfaction. The very early levels provide a good example of this game's whole vibe, with gameplay hints disguised in three or four words that you have to look at in relation to the current level and what you need to do. That's hard to explain too, I'm not doing it well. Lyne is calming and focusing at the same time, and I would have gladly paid full price for it. Heck, I would've happily paid like ten bucks for it if it was that price and I had a chance to try it out first. Do yourself a favor, even if you're not a huge fan of puzzle games, and buy this game. Also buy copies for everyone you know, if it's on sale. 11/10 excellent flawless game.

You'll encounter puzzles that are morecomplex than the other and may require you some time to figure out how to solve it.  Another reason why it's outstanding is the challenge is very rewarding. There are times when you might find surprising yourself. (Those are the moments when it seems like your eyes and hands coordinate without you knowing and the puzzle gets solved instantly. I don't know why or how, but it usually happens when my thoughts are lost on other things. LOL.)  I, generally, recommend this game to those who love and are into puzzle games. A puzzle game where the objective is to connect all shapes of similar shape/color along finite number of lines. LInes cannot cross, but some shapes will accept any line color and can accept a line multiple times.  That's it.  Pros: + Easy to pick up + Gets gradually difficult + You will not run out of levels, because the game generates daily puzzles + There's like 650 pre-built puzzles anyway, this game will take you at least 10 hours + Steam trading cards + The achievements are letters, and you can use them to spell things in your steam achievement showcase. If you're bad at puzzles, you can just look at one of the many walkthroughs and enjoy your ill-gotten showcase; nobody will know. + Costs less than a couple of tacos + Soothing flute  Cons: -   Points of note: ? No soundtrack (there is audio as you interact with the pieces and finish stages), but this lets you put on any kind of ambient music that you want. This would be a con, but I don't think it's reasonable to expect this game to have a 10+ hour soundtrack.  ? It's a puzzle game, so if you don't like puzzle games, don't buy it. ? Casual  Edit: After beating the game (all the puzzles and some of the random daily ones) I can't say this game was mind-bendingly difficult, but I did get stuck on a few levels from time to time. The solution to that was usually to just go away and do somthing else and then come back to the puzzle with a fresh mind after a day or a few.

A very simple premise that is used in an amazing variety of ways. The puzzles always start out overwhelming, but after bashing away at them a bit you start to pick up on patterns and before you know it, you've solved it. And I really mean that, sometimes you do just stumble upon a solution without realising you're close, but that's just a product of the game's nature: There's no failure except failing to continue. It encourages you to just try things, experiment with new routes, and try and get past some of your initial perceptions. There are more paths than you might think, and often there are multiple ways to solve a puzzle. Good luck.
